docs.snippet: Off Broadway's New York Theater Workshop on Friday announced two additional productions for its 2011-12 season: a play about a Palestinian family preparing for a wedding in the politically volatile West Bank, and a modern retelling of Homer's ''Il...
docs.abstract: New York Theater Workshop, Off Broadway, adds productions of Lisa Peterson and Denis O'Hare play An Iliad and Lameece Issaq play Food and Fadwa to its 2011-12 season. (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Off Broadway's New York Theater Workshop on Friday announced two additional productions for its 2011-12 season: a play about a Palestinian family preparing for a wedding in the politically volatile West Bank, and a modern retelling of Homer's ''Illiad'' that will feature, on alternating nights, the Tony Award winners Denis O'Hare (''Take Me Out'') and Stephen Spinella (''Angels in America'') as the piece's sole actor. The workshop had previously disclosed that the first show of the season will be Elevator Repair Service's latest novel-based production ''The Select - The Sun Also Rises,'' made up of swaths of dialogue and prose from Hemingway's classic about American expatriates in France and Spain after World War I. Elevator Repair Service had a major critical hit this season at the Public Theater with ''Gatz,'' a word-for-word rendition of Fitzgerald's ''The Great Gatsby.'' Previously at the workshop, the theater troupe mounted a production based on the first section of Faulkner's ''The Sound and the Fury.''

headline.main: Theater Workshop Adds Two More Productions

docs.snippet: TO me, there is no important occasion, be it an anniversary, a religious festival or a simple coming together of friends, -- that does not beg for a meal to celebrate it. I also think that any meal, however basic, is a symbolic celebration of bein...
docs.abstract: Nigella Lawson article on celebrating holidays with food; offers recipes from her recent book Feast: Food to Celebrate Life; photo (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: TO me, there is no important occasion, be it an anniversary, a religious festival or a simple coming together of friends, -- that does not beg for a meal to celebrate it. I also think that any meal, however basic, is a symbolic celebration of being alive. I know it does not always feel this way in our harried world, but that doesn't make it any less true. Food sustains us not only physically, but also emotionally. At this time of year, with Thanksgiving behind us, Hanukkah just starting and Christmas and New Year's in the wings, we are more alive to the meaning of a feast. What I love about cooking is that we can share in other people's festivals.

headline.main: A Feast for a Holiday, Or Everyday Exulting
